doc.title: TTL

value.content: Time To Live (TTL) can refer to either the lifetime of a packet in a network, or the expiry time of cached data.

value.title: Networking
value.content: In networking, the TTL, embedded in the packet, is a usually defined as a number of hops or as an expiration timestamp after which the packet is dropped. It provides a way to avoids network congestion, but releasing packets after they roamed the network too long.

value.title: Caching
value.content: In the context of caching, TTL (as an unsigned 32-bit integer) being a part of the HTTP response header or the DNS query, indicates the amount of time in seconds during which the resource can be cached by the requester.

value.title: See also
value.content:
• TTL on Wikipedia
  • RFC 2181 on IETF
  • RFC1035 on IETF
